entry.title: TDC S√£o Paulo
entry.content:
üéôÔ∏è Talk: Uncovering Tests: Creating Secure and Resilient Systems
ü§ù Feat: Larissa Azevedo

Summary
  • Test the functionality of our application? ‚úÖ
  • Break our application before the user or an attacker? That's different.

Let's demystify test coverage and understand how to create tests that make our application predictable against the unpredictable.

More than just testing, you will learn to create secure validations and understand in practice the impact of data transformation.

And if you think security is just about code, even the LGPD will come through here from the perspective of someone who managed to access our database.

The idea is for you to realize that tests are not an additional task: they are part of our application and are essential for digital and human security.

Let's demystify test coverage and understand how to create tests that make our application predictable against the unpredictable.

entry.title: MVP Conf: Tech Talk
entry.content:
üìπ Palestra (Live): GitHub Beyond Code: overcoming in the job market through open source

note

Aimed at new developers, I spoke about the impact that open source and GitHub can have on our careers, on the TechTalk program from the MVP Conf channel, hosted by Vanessa Valle and Renata Correa.

Focusing on how to stand out in an increasingly competitive market, I show how open source can accelerate your technical growth, enabling you to achieve unimaginable milestones that directly impact your professional career.

In a market that is more competitive every day, open source is not just about code ‚Äî it's a direct bridge to technical growth, global visibility, and real career opportunities.

With visual, human, and real examples, I want to inspire you and bring an optimistic perspective of yourself in an increasingly intimidating world, especially with the rise of artificial intelligence, using open source strategically to build credibility and trust in the market.

tip

You can watch the live replay on the official MVP Conf YouTube channel ‚ú®

entry.title: Semana de Sistemas de Informa√ß√£o (EACH-USP)
entry.content:
üéôÔ∏è Keynote: GitHub Beyond Code: overcoming in the job market through open source

note

Speaking at a university (USP) is special in itself, but closing the day's event made it even more special ‚ú®

The SSI is an event organized by the university students themselves, and I had the pleasure of being invited to teach through open source, using GitHub as a learning tool.

Focusing on how to stand out in an increasingly competitive market, I show how open source can accelerate your technical growth, enabling you to achieve unimaginable milestones that directly impact your professional career.

In a market that is more competitive every day, open source is not just about code ‚Äî it's a direct bridge to technical growth, global visibility, and real career opportunities.

With visual, human, and real examples, I want to inspire you and bring an optimistic perspective of yourself in an increasingly intimidating world, especially with the rise of artificial intelligence, using open source strategically to build credibility and trust in the market.

entry.title: DevConverge LATAM & Oracle ‚Äî SPRINT SP
entry.content:
üéôÔ∏è Talk: Inventing the New: The Meeting Point Between Human Creativity and AI-Assisted Generation

note

Improving performance in a legacy system is part of the routine. Inventing algorithms and a brand-new architecture is something completely different.

In this talk, I share the behind-the-scenes of rebuilding a critical open source ecosystem library, MySQL2, to efficiently process billions of MySQL requests.

We'll go through the problems, ideas, implementations, how to teach LLMs to handle something new, and even the remediation of 4 large-scale critical vulnerabilities (CVEs).

Additionally, you'll learn about the process of making the largest MySQL client for JavaScript compatible with TypeScript, Bun, Deno, and Cloudflare Workers.

entry.title: Codecon Summit ‚Äî Embrace the Hacker Way
entry.content:
üéôÔ∏è Talk: Creating a Test Runner: What happens behind the tests?

note

There's a lot of talk about testing, but what's it like to create a test runner from scratch?
More than that: how do you test a test runner?

In this talk, I break down Poku, the only Brazilian test runner for JavaScript and TypeScript, which challenges more than 14 years of language history by bringing native JavaScript syntax to tests.

You'll learn about the power of subprocesses, isolation, and the advantages of working with concurrency‚Äîall using only native language features.

Wait, native syntax?

You'll discover the history of testing in JavaScript and why tests don't follow the natural flow of the language, while uncovering the inner workings of the most popular test runners.

This is the kind of insight that, regardless of which tester you use, will change the way you truly see testing.

entry.title: Winx Day (Luciano dii Souza ‚Äî O Primo Dev)
entry.content:
üìπ Live (Talk): Overcoming impostor syndrome and the challenges of existing in the market through open source.

info

An online event organized by Luciano dii Souza, with a relaxed approach and held through the Discord community for developers, aiming to share experiences and knowledge, especially for those who are just starting in the field.

At this moment when many developers feel insecure about the future of the field:

  • Is my level sufficient?
  • Should I give up if I can't get a job in my field?
  • How do I gain experience if the market doesn't give me opportunities?
  • After all, will Artificial Intelligence replace developers or not?

Bringing up sensitive topics like insecurity, inferiority complex, and self-sabotage, with a light at the end of the tunnel through open source initiatives, was quite challenging but very interesting.

This is a talk where I expose the insecurities during my journey, speaking in a tone close to what would be a heartfelt confession.

The intention is to connect with those participating, evolve toward learning, and perhaps inspire through my story, sharing the human side that social networks and "LinkedIn titles" don't show.

entry.title: GitHub Brasil ‚Äî Open Source Friday
entry.content:
üìπ Talk (Live): Meeting Poku.

note

In a conversation that was both technical and casual, I had the honor of kicking off the very first edition of Open Source Friday by GitHub Brasil, hosted by Pachi Parra.

During the live session, I was able to share a bit about myself, the importance of open source, motivations, challenges, and future plans for Poku, as well as give some great tips for those who want to contribute for the first time, especially for those who feel insecure.

In one hour of live streaming, there were conversations, low vs. too-high microphone volume, explanations about module systems, and the differences in behavior between Node.js, Bun, and Deno.

There was even live coding, demonstrating in practice why other test runners are not fully compatible with all JavaScript backends and how Poku challenges more than 12 years of language history by bringing JavaScript's natural flow to testing.

tip

You can replay the live session on the official GitHub Brasil LinkedIn üê∑

entry.title: DevFest Cerrado (Google Developer Groups ‚Äî GDG)
entry.content:
üéôÔ∏è Talk: Overcoming the impostor syndrome and the challenges of existing in the industry through open-source.

note

At a time when many developers feel insecure about the future of the field, bringing up sensitive topics like insecurity, inferiority complex, and self-sabotage, with a light at the end of the tunnel through open source initiatives, was quite challenging but very interesting:

üí° Choosing the topic‚Äã

  • Is my skill level enough?
  • Should I give up if I can't get a job in my area?
  • How can I gain experience if the market doesn't give me opportunities?

üßëüèª‚Äçüî¨ The development‚Äã

I could have easily explained what impostor syndrome is and gone straight to the ‚Äúsolution,‚Äù but I chose the harder path:

‚Äî Exposing my weaknesses throughout my journey, speaking in a tone close to a heartfelt confession.

The goal was to connect with those present, evolve into learning, and maybe inspire through my story, sharing the human side that social media and "LinkedIn titles" don't show.

üëª The challenges‚Äã

Talking about our flaws and insecurities to people who don't even know us is more complicated than it seems; people like to listen to someone they can admire.

But the comments and affection from people who came to talk to me at the end showed me that the idea of connecting with those present not only worked but truly inspired some people, and that made me very happy ‚ú®

üé§ The talk‚Äã

I wondered if people would be interested in this topic, but gradually the room filled up and someone even sat on the floor at the very beginning.

Originally, the presentation included some additional studies, including practical screens with real open source contributions, but I had to adapt some things to fit the event's format and time.

tip

Spoiler (GIF) of the slide used in the talk:

entry.title: Microsoft Reactor and NodeBR
entry.content:
üéôÔ∏è Talk: Creating a High-Performance Multi-Platform Test Runner.

note

The focus of the talk was on the importance of delegating each problem's responsibilities using native Node.js features.

With the theme "API Like a Boss", I had the opportunity to teach using Poku.

Instead of just talking about Poku itself, I also used Poku as an analogy, teaching about subprocesses and the differences between Node.js, Bun, and Deno.

tip

See the slides used in the talk üê∑
